heisig_chinese_memo: A shellfish carrying one page balanced on its head.
heisig_constituent: page, one, ceiling, drop, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight
heisig_story: What we have to do here is turn a shellfish into a page of a book. The one at the top tells us that we only get a rather short book, in fact only one page. Imagine a title printed on the shell of an oyster, let us say "Pearl of Wisdom," and then open the quaint book to its one and only page, on which you find a single, radiant drop of wisdom, one of the masterpiece poems of nature.

humanum_full_description_en:
The head and body of a person like a gold inscription. The head is set off by the smallness of the human body, so the original meaning of " page " is the head. The difference between " page " and " shou " lies in whether or not the human body is drawn when writing, so the two characters are variants. See " first ". The word " page " in oracle bones may have hair on the head, or omit the shape of the hair. There are hairs on the heads of the characters " page " in the inscriptions of the Western Zhou Dynasty inscriptions of the Western Zhou Dynasty. The characters of the Warring States Period are more corrupted, while the small seals omit the hair on the heads.

The word " page " oracle bone inscriptions is used as the original meaning, such as "Collection" 15684: "Pig Page", which means the head of a pig. Another example is "Collection" 22215: "Five sons knocking the page", which means five boys knocking their heads.

" Page " in inscriptions can be found on the cover of Mao ğ£ª•: "Mao worships the hands and pages of the hands." Other inscriptions are mostly written as "the firsts of the hands of worship", handed down documents such as "Shang Shu. Zhou Shu. "Zhaogao" is called "Beishou Jishou". "Bai Shou Ji Shou" is the ancient ritual of kneeling, that is, bowing to hands and bowing to the ground. "Ji Shou" is written as "page hand" only for this to see, it may be a provincial language, Ji Xusheng thinks " page " or a typo. "Said Wen": "Page, head also. From ğ¦£» from the child. The ancient prose is like this, all pages belong to the page."

" Page " and " shou " were originally the same character, sounded " shou ", and then the word " page " was changed to "Hu Jieqie" in the Eastern Han Dynasty at the latest. As for " page " as the quantifier of paper, it is a vulgar word, originally " leaf ". See " leaf ".
humanum_short_description_en: Jia Jin inscription from " Jie " from " first ", like a kneeling person, and highlights its head. "Said Wen": "Page, head also."

Heisig: What we have to do here is turn a shellfish into a page of a book. The one at the top tells us that we only get a rather short book, in fact only one page. Imagine a title printed on the shell of an oyster, let us say "Pearl of Wisdom," and then open the quaint book to its one and only page, on which you find a single, radiant drop of wisdom, one of the masterpiece poems of nature.
* As a primitive, this kanji takes the unrelated meaning of a head (preferably one detached from its body), derived from the character for head (Frame 1549).

The head and body of a person like a gold inscription. The head is set off by the smallness of the human body, so the original meaning of " page" is the head. The difference between " page" and " shou" lies in whether or not the human body is drawn when writing, so the two characters are variants. See " first". The word " page" in oracle bones may have hair on the head, or omit the shape of the hair. There are hairs on the heads of the characters " page" in the inscriptions of the Western Zhou Dynasty inscriptions of the Western Zhou Dynasty. The characters of the Warring States Period are more corrupted, while the small seals omit the hair on the heads. The word " page" oracle bone inscriptions is used as the original meaning, such as "Collection" 15684: "Pig Page", which means the head of a pig. Another example is "Collection" 22215: "Five sons knocking the page", which means five boys knocking their heads. " Page" in inscriptions can be found on the cover of Mao ğ£ª•: "Mao worships the hands and pages of the hands." Other inscriptions are mostly written as "the firsts of the hands of worship", handed down documents such as "Shang Shu. Zhou Shu. "Zhaogao" is called "Beishou Jishou". "Bai Shou Ji Shou" is the ancient ritual of kneeling, that is, bowing to hands and bowing to the ground. "Ji Shou" is written as "page hand" only for this to see, it may be a provincial language, Ji Xusheng thinks " page" or a typo. "Said Wen": "Page, head also. From ğ¦£» from the child. The ancient prose is like this, all pages belong to the page." " Page" and " shou" were originally the same character, sounded " shou", and then the word " page" was changed to "Hu Jieqie" in the Eastern Han Dynasty at the latest. As for " page" as the quantifier of paper, it is a vulgar word, originally " leaf". See " leaf".
